channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2017 The New York Times Company

item.title: Questions Cloud U.S. Raid on Qaeda Branch in Yemen
item.media:description: Officials, including Senator Chris Coons of Delaware, left Washington for Dover Air Force Base on Wednesday to meet the family of an American commando killed in Yemen.
item.description: One commando was killed and civilian casualties were also likely, raising doubts about the planning of the counterterrorism operation, the first authorized by President Trump.
item.dc:creator: ERIC SCHMITT and DAVID E. SANGER
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: 1,000 Officers and One Arrest: German Terror Raids Sow Doubts
item.media:description: The German police outside a mosque in Frankfurt on Wednesday, when they raided more than 50 sites.
item.description: The authorities raided more than 50 sites in a show of force, but the result just renewed questions of whether the country’s security apparatus can deal with the threat.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE

item.title: German Bishops Open Way to Communion for Divorced Catholics
item.media:description: The Cathedral of St. Bartholomew, a Roman Catholic church in Frankfurt. Many German bishops are generally considered to be within the more liberal wing of the Catholic Church.
item.description: The guidelines do not require priests to offer the sacrament but allow them to do so on a case-by-case basis.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: Fearful of Hacking, Dutch Will Count Ballots by Hand
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Rutte of the Netherlands speaking at a college.
item.description: The decision to forgo electronic counting, in national elections scheduled for next month, was a response to fears that outside actors, like Russia, might try to tamper with the election.
item.dc:creator: SEWELL CHAN

item.title: The Phrase Putin Never Uses About Terrorism (and Trump Does)
item.media:description: Vladimir V. Putin visiting a mosque in Grozny in 2008 with the Chechen leader Ramzan Kadyrov.
item.description: The Russian leader, whom President Trump admires for his pull-no-punches style, avoids the term “radical Islamic terrorism” to emphasize the distinction from religion.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW E. KRAMER

item.title: Trump Pushes Dark View of Islam to Center of U.S. Policy-Making
item.media:description: President Trump on the phone last weekend with Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia. With the president in the Oval Office were his national security adviser, Michael T. Flynn, center, and his top strategist, Stephen K. Bannon.
item.description: A vision of Islam as inherently hostile has long flourished on the far right. Now President Trump has brought that view to the White House.
item.dc:creator: SCOTT SHANE, MATTHEW ROSENBERG and ERIC LIPTON

item.title: Pentagon Clears Officials of Skewing Data in ISIS Reports
item.description: The results of an inquiry ran counter to a widespread view among military analysts that the reports painted a rosy picture of progress against the Islamic State.
item.dc:creator: MARK MAZZETTI and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: West Bank Settlers Clash With Israeli Police Sent to Evict Them
item.media:description: Israeli security forces tried to arrest settlers and activists during the evacuation of Amona.
item.description: Hundreds of people barricaded themselves in buildings when Israeli security forces operating under a court order arrived to forcibly evacuate settlers from Amona.
item.dc:creator: THE NEW YORK TIMES

item.title: Iran Is Threatened With U.S. Reprisals Over Missile Test
item.media:description: President Hassan Rouhani, left, on Wednesday in Tehran at an exhibition of Iran’s achievements in space technology.
item.media:credit: Office of the Iranian Presidency, via Associated Press
item.description: “We are officially putting Iran on notice,” said Michael T. Flynn, the national security adviser, though he did not specify exactly how the administration would respond.
item.dc:creator: MARK LANDLER and THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: Authoritarian Leaders Greet Trump as One of Their Own
item.media:description: Kim Jong-un, the leader of North Korea, this month. Donald J. Trump said in May that he would have “no problem” meeting with Mr. Kim.
item.description: Leaders like Vladimir V. Putin of Russia and Rodrigo Duterte of the Philippines seem to see a respite from criticism and a chance to advance nationalist goals.
item.dc:creator: ROD NORDLAND

item.title: In South Korea, Defense Secretary Mattis Tries to Reassure an Ally
item.media:description: Defense Secretary Jim Mattis at Osan Air Base in South Korea on Thursday. South Korea is the first stop on his trip. He will also visit Japan before returning to Washington.
item.description: On his first trip abroad, Defense Secretary Jim Mattis said he would talk to the country’s leaders about a defense system designed to intercept North Korean missiles.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON and CHOE SANG-HUN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Mexico Takes First Step Before Talks With U.S. on Nafta
item.media:description: The Mexican government, under President Enrique Peña Nieto, is intent on preserving the North American Free Trade Agreement and the $1.4 billion in trade that crosses the United States-Mexico border on a daily basis.
item.media:credit: Press Office of the President of Mexico, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: The government said it was beginning a 90-day consultation with the Senate and private sector before talks to review the trade accord with the United States.
item.dc:creator: ELISABETH MALKIN

item.title: U.N. Leader Says Trump Visa Bans ‘Violate Our Basic Principles’
item.media:description: Demonstrators gathered at Kennedy Airport over the weekend to protest President Trump’s executive order barring refugees and citizens of seven predominantly Muslim countries.
item.media:credit: Christopher Lee for The New York Times
item.description: Secretary General António Guterres, in his first detailed remarks on the immigration restrictions, also said they would not reduce terrorist threats.
item.dc:creator: SOMINI SENGUPTA

item.title: What in the World: Polish City to Give Tom Hanks the Car That Put It on the Auto Map
item.media:description: A gathering of Fiat 126p enthusiasts in Krakow, Poland. “The Maluch was the beginning of an automotive revolution in Poland,” said Jacek Krywult, the mayor of Bielsko-Biala, Poland, where the car was made.
item.description: The Maluch, built in Bielsko-Biala from the early 1970s to 2000, has developed a following that apparently includes at least one prominent fan.
item.dc:creator: RICK LYMAN

item.title: U.S.-Australia Rift Is Possible After Trump Ends Call With Prime Minister
item.media:description: Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull of Australia said that despite the bluntness of the discussion with President Trump, the United States had committed to upholding the arrangement to accept 1,250 refugees from an Australian detention center.
item.description: A phone call between President Trump and Malcolm Turnbull turned contentious after the Australian leader pressed Mr. Trump to accept 1,250 refugees.
item.dc:creator: GLENN THRUSH and MICHELLE INNIS

item.title: India’s New Budget Aims to Spur Economy, Hit Hard by Cash Shortage
item.media:description: A market in New Dehli. The Indian government unveiled its budget plan on Wednesday. It included tax cuts for lower income taxpayers and small businesses.
item.description: The budget plan includes tax cuts for lower income taxpayers and small businesses, as well as higher spending on infrastructure, rural development and antipoverty programs.
item.dc:creator: GEETA ANAND

item.title: Turkey and Greece Trade Jabs in Island Dispute
item.media:description: Supporters of the Greek far-right Golden Dawn party during a commemoration of the 21st anniversary of the dispute over the islands known as Imia in Greece and Kardak in Turkey.
item.description: A decades-old quarrel over two islets has flared, some say in response to a Greek court’s refusal to extradite eight Turkish airmen.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK KINGSLEY

item.title: Theresa May Gets Parliament’s Backing on ‘Brexit’ Bill
item.media:description: Prime Minister Theresa May headed to the Houses of Parliament in London on Wednesday.
item.description: A vote in the House of Commons was not the final verdict, but with 498 for and 114 against, any efforts to slow Britain’s withdrawal from the European Union appeared certain to fail.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: For Syrian Girl in Need of Medical Care, Trump’s Travel Ban Adds to a Nomadic Tragedy
item.media:description: Sham Aldaher, carried by her father, Ali, on her way to an operating room at Sant Joan de Déu hospital in Barcelona, Spain, in December. A hospital program uses clowns to put children at ease.
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.description: The parents of Sham Aldaher, who has a rare birth defect, had cleared all security checks and were planning to settle the family in the United States, but their plans are now blocked.
item.dc:creator: RAPHAEL MINDER

item.title: Taveuni Island Journal: A Rare Pacific Islander Captivates Its Neighborhood
item.media:description: Tagimoucia has attained a kind of celebrity status because of its beauty and rarity.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: Tagimoucia, a crimson and white flower, grows mainly on a single mountain ridge in Fiji. It has a magical significance to Fijians.
item.dc:creator: SERENA SOLOMON

item.title: Graft Allegations Grow Against François Fillon, French Presidential Hopeful
item.media:description: The French presidential candidate François Fillon at a campaign rally on Sunday in Paris.
item.description: A newspaper claimed that Mr. Fillon’s wife held a bogus, taxpayer-funded job even longer than initially reported.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Ban Ki-moon Says He Won’t Run for President of South Korea
item.media:description: Ban Ki-moon, whose term as United Nations secretary general just ended, had been seen as a viable contender to succeed the embattled president, despite progressives’ skepticism.
item.description: The former U.N. chief’s surprise announcement deprived conservatives of their likeliest candidate to succeed the sidelined president, Park Geun-hye.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Communist Rebels in Philippines Say They’ll End Cease-Fire
item.media:description: Members of the New People’s Army, a Communist rebel group, in the Philippine province of Quezon last year. At least 35,000 fighters and civilians have died in the four-decade conflict.
item.description: The armed wing of the Communist Party of the Philippines accused the government of failing to release political prisoners and the military of encroaching on rebel territory.
item.dc:creator: FELIPE VILLAMOR

item.title: Israel Defiantly Cranks West Bank Settlement Plans Into High Gear
item.media:description: A construction site in the Israeli settlement of Ma’ale Adumim in the West Bank, near Jerusalem.
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.description: Even as officials forcibly evacuated the illegal Amona settlement, two moves by Israel opened a forceful new phase of expansion into land the Palestinians claim for a future state.
item.dc:creator: IAN FISHER and ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Myanmar Arrests 4 in Fatal Shooting of Prominent Rights Lawyer
item.media:description: Members of the governing National League for Democracy party provided security during the funeral of U Ko Ni on Monday, in Yangon, Myanmar. The president’s office said this week that the killing was carried out to “undermine the country’s stability.”
item.description: The death of U Ko Ni, a Muslim and an adviser to Myanmar’s leader, has raised new concerns about the country’s rocky transition to democracy.
item.dc:creator: SAW NANG and GERRY MULLANY

item.title: ‘I Didn’t Want to Lose My Identity’: 16,000 Readers Reflect on Their Surnames
item.media:description: Katherine Yuk from Toronto was one of more than 16,000 readers who responded when The New York Times asked women around the world why they kept or changed their surnames when they married.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: The Times asked women around the world why they had kept or changed their surnames when they married. For many, the decision carried significant weight.
item.dc:creator: HANNA INGBER

item.title: 15 of the Best Journals by Our Reporters Around the World
item.media:description: A man folding blankets that are rented out to the homeless in Delhi.
item.media:credit: Daniel Berehulak for The New York Times
item.description: The conversational and visual on-the-ground reports offered a glimpse of captivating people and places, from a “sleep mafia” in Delhi to a monastery seeking salvation in beer.
item.dc:creator: Compiled by BARBARA TIERNEY

item.title: Editorial: Bangladesh’s Crackdown on Labor
item.media:description: A fire at a garment factory in September outside Dhaka, Bangladesh, killed at least 24 people.
item.description: Firings and criminal complaints against activists are intended to intimidate workers and maintain low wages.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: The Art of the Deal in Afghanistan
item.media:description: Afghan security forces inspecting the site of two large-scale bombings in Kabul last month.
item.description: President Trump will have to talk to the Taliban.
item.dc:creator: BARNETT R. RUBIN
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Trump: The Art of the Deal (Book)

item.title: Editorial: Quebec’s Response to Hate: More Tolerance
item.media:description: Cardinal Gérald Cyprien Lacroix, middle left, archbishop of Quebec, embracing Boufeldja Banabdallah, co-founder of the Quebec Islamic Cultural Center, at a special Mass this week following the Sunday shooting.
item.media:credit: Ian Willms for The New York Times
item.description: After six people were shot to death at a mosque, the nation was shocked, but its commitment to inclusion did not falter.
item.dc:creator: THE EDITORIAL BOARD
